Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on Including Ethics in Data Science Pedagogy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) and data science technologies are increasingly being used in making consequential decisions such as determining whether someone is hired, promoted, offered a loan, or provided housing. Many of these systems however were developed and some deployed without a careful assessment of their societal impact. For example, AI systems have been shown to exhibit gender and racial biases in making hiring and sentencing decisions. Yet, many data science students and practitioners are still unaware of the prevalence and seriousness of these issues. Equipping them with the knowledge to understand the implications of algorithm design decisions as well as tools that they can use to mitigate the biases in these systems is the key to ensure that the data-driven decision making systems they build are fair and trustworthy. This serves the national interest by furthering NSF's mission to promote the progress of science, and to advance the national health, prosperity and welfare.

This two day workshop brings together prominent educators, researchers and thought leaders from academia, industry and government together to explore ideas on the best strategies to develop data science ethics curricula. During the workshop, participants explore ideas on the best strategies to develop data science ethics curricula that are guided by pedagogical principles, informed by the needs of communities, aligned with core social values and laws, and shaped by the latest evidence and solutions from the fairness, accountability and transparency in AI research. The key outcomes of the workshop include a recommendation for incorporating ethics in data science pedagogy that contains guidelines on designing both standalone data science ethics courses as well as ethics modules that can be embedded in existing data science courses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) and data science technologies are increasingly being used in making consequential decisions such as determining whether someone is hired, promoted, offered a loan, or provided housing. Many of these technologies however were developed and some deployed without a careful assessment of their societal impact or implicit assumptions. Educating the next generation of data scientists with the knowledge to understand and mitigate the biases in these systems is key to ensure that future data-driven decision making systems are fair, trustworthy and will not negatively impact the health and well-being of our society, but rather seek to expand equity and justice. The main goal of the Workshop on Including Ethics in Data Science Pedagogy is to develop data science ethics curricula that are guided by pedagogical principles, informed by the needs of communities, aligned with core social values and laws, and shaped by the latest evidence and solutions from the fairness, accountability and transparency in AI research.

The workshop was held on June 17-18, 2019 in Alexandria, Virginia. It brought together over fifty prominent educators, researchers and thought leaders from academia, industry and government together to explore ideas on the best strategies to develop data science ethics curricula. The workshop included co-keynote to frame the theme of the workshop from multi-disciplinary perspectives; two panel-styled stakeholder presentations to discuss needs, concerns, and challenges; two lightning talk sessions provided a forum for educators to share their own experiences in embedding or teaching data science ethics. To further engage workshop participants, the workshop also included two breakout sessions and one participant presentation session. The breakout sessions allowed the participants to work together to identify and address the main challenges when teaching data science ethics in different scenarios, such as embedding ethics in data science courses and in dedicated courses taught by social scientists or other experts ; teaching undergraduate courses compared to graduate courses; teaching students with different backgrounds and preparations. Nine workshop participants volunteered to share their thoughts and experiences from diverse perspectives at the participant presentation session. 

The workshop concluded with key takeaways and next steps. The participants highlighted the need for hearing from others including students, industry partners, career advisors, and community voices. There are clearly domains such as medical, legal, and engineering domains, where people have been discussing issues around the pedagogy of ethics who can be engaged in this conversation. It is also essential to acknowledge and remedy the ways in which computing and data technologies have not been inclusive in the past, or continue to be part of unjust social structures (e.g., racism and discrimination). The participants discussed the need for including multiple facets of ethics and responsible Data Science that includes intersecting aspects such as legal compliance issues which are critical and can have far reaching impact for industry and society. There was a sense of urgency that was brought up in inculcating a culture of responsibility by design, which is much harder to do but various venues can be used to start engaging leaders such as the Data Science leadership summits, and CRA retreats. Participants highlighted the importance of educating the educator including faculty at all levels and graduate students as well as providing proper incentive and institutional support to encourage educators to develop new ethics courses or modules. Clearly there is a need for shared resources for faculty and students. Resources such as syllabi, artifacts, case studies, and data sets can help jump start curriculum development in various types of institutions, helping keep apace with the data science classes and degrees popping up. Some of these resources are needed even after students leave their institutions and encounter ethical dilemmas in their work environments. Several codes of conduct such as the ABET, IEEE, and ACM code of ethics were brought up at the workshop. The participants felt there was a need to have guidance on navigating the landscape of code of conducts from various organizations.

Overall, the workshop participants provided valuable feedback on the main ethics topics to teach in data science courses, the challenges in teaching these topics to students with diverse backgrounds and preparations, as well as the strategies that can be used to address these challenges.
